description: From Middle English mark, merk, merke, from Old English mearc (“mark, sign, line of division; standard; boundary, limit, term, border; defined area, district, province”), from Proto-West Germanic *marku, from Proto-Germanic *markō (“boundary; boundary marker”), from Proto-Indo-European *marǵ- (“edge, boundary, border”).

Cognate with Dutch mark, merk (“mark, brand”), German Mark (“mark; borderland”), Swedish mark (“mark, land, territory”), Icelandic mark (“mark, sign”), Latin margo (“edge, margin”), Persian مرز‎ (marz, “limit, boundary”), Sanskrit मर्या (maryā, “limit, mark, boundary”) and मार्ग (mārga, “mark, section”). Compare march.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A boundary; a border or frontier. [9th–19th c.]
(obsolete) A boundary-post or fence. [13th–18th c.]
A stone or post used to indicate position and guide travellers. [from 14th c.]
examples: I do remember a great thron in Yatton field near Bristow-way, against which Sir William Waller's men made a great fire and killed it. I think the stump remains, and was a mark for travellers.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A type of small region or principality. [from 18th c.]
examples: There dwells Théoden son of Thengel, King of the Mark of Rohan.

entries.meaning: (historical) A common, or area of common land, especially among early Germanic peoples. [from 19th c.]
An omen; a symptomatic indicator of something. [from 8th c.]
A characteristic feature. [from 16th c.]
examples: A good sense of manners is the mark of a true gentleman.

entries.meaning: A visible impression or sign; a blemish, scratch, or stain, whether accidental or intentional. [from 9th c.]
A sign or brand on a person. [from 10th c.]
A written character or sign. [from 10th c.]
examples: The font wasn't able to render all the diacritical marks properly.

entries.meaning: A stamp or other indication of provenance, quality etc. [from 11th c.]
examples: With eggs, you need to check for the quality mark before you buy.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Resemblance, likeness, image. [14th–16th c.]
A particular design or make of an item (now usually with following numeral). [from 15th c.]
examples: I am proud to present my patented travelator, mark two.

entries.meaning: A score for finding the correct answer, or other academic achievement; the sum of such points gained as out of a possible total. [from 19th c.]
examples: What mark did you get in your history test?

entries.meaning: A target for shooting at with a projectile. [from 13th c.]
examples: A skilfull archer ought first to know the marke he aimeth at, and then apply his hand, his bow, his string, his arrow and his motion accordingly.

entries.meaning: An indication or sign used for reference or measurement. [from 14th c.]
examples: I filled the bottle up to the 500ml mark.

entries.meaning: The target or intended victim of a swindle, fixed game or con game. [from 18th c.]
(obsolete) The female genitals. [16th–18th c.]
(Rugby football, Australian rules football) A catch of the ball directly from a kick of 10 metres or more without having been touched in transit, resulting in a free kick. [from 19th c.]
(sports) The line indicating an athlete's starting-point. [from 19th c.]
A score for a sporting achievement. [from 20th c.]
An official note that is added to a record kept about someone's behavior or performance.
examples: A mark for tardiness or for absence is considered by most pupils a disgrace, and strenuous efforts are made to avoid such a mark.

entries.meaning: (cooking) A specified level on a scale denoting gas-powered oven temperatures. [from 20th c.]
examples: Now put the pastry in at 450 degrees, or mark 8.

entries.meaning: (product design/engineering) The model number of a device; a device model.
examples: The Mark I system had poor radar, and the Mark II was too expensive; regardless, most antiaircraft direction remained the responsibility of the Mark I Eyeball (as the jocular phrase calls it): that is, the operator's eye.

entries.meaning: Limit or standard of action or fact.
examples: to be within the mark
to come up to the mark

entries.meaning: Badge or sign of honour, rank, or official station.
(archaic) Preeminence; high position.
examples: patricians of mark
a fellow of no mark

entries.meaning: (logic) A characteristic or essential attribute; a differential.
(nautical) One of the bits of leather or coloured bunting placed upon a sounding line at intervals of from two to five fathoms. (The unmarked fathoms are called "deeps".)
(archaic) Attention, notice. [from 15th c.]
examples: His last comment is particularly worthy of mark.

entries.meaning: Importance, noteworthiness. (Generally in postmodifier “of mark”.) [from 16th c.]
examples: in the short story of western flavor he was a pioneer of mark, the founder of a genre: probably no other writer is so significant in his field.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Regard; respect.

verbs.description: mark (third-person singular simple present marks, present participle marking, simple past and past participle marked)

entries.meaning: To put a mark on (something); to make (something) recognizable by a mark; to label or write on (something).
examples: to mark a box or bale of merchandise
to mark clothing with one's name

entries.meaning: To leave a mark (often an undesirable or unwanted one) on (something).
examples: Synonyms: blemish, scar, scratch, stain
See where this pencil has marked the paper.
The floor was marked with wine and blood.

entries.meaning: (figurative) To have a long-lasting negative impact on (someone or something).
examples: The death of his wife, followed by months of being alone, had marked him with guilt and shame and had left an unbreaking loneliness on him.

entries.meaning: To create an indication of (a location).
examples: She folded over the corner of the page to mark where she left off reading.
Some animals mark their territory by urinating.

entries.meaning: To be an indication of (something); to show where (something) is located.
examples: This monument marks the spot where Wolfe died.
A bell marked the end of visiting hours.
Synonyms: demonstrate, indicate, manifest, reveal, show, signal

entries.meaning: To indicate (something) in writing or by other symbols.
examples: Prices are marked on individual items.
In her Bible, the words of Christ were marked in red.
Synonyms: display, show, write

entries.meaning: To create (a mark) on a surface.
examples: Synonyms: draw, trace

entries.meaning: To celebrate or acknowledge (an event) through an action of some kind.
examples: The national holiday is marked by fireworks.
Synonyms: commemorate, solemnize

entries.meaning: (of things) To identify (someone as a particular type of person or as having a particular role).
examples: His courage and energy marked him as a leader.

entries.meaning: (of people) To assign (someone) to a particular category or class.
examples: Synonyms: classify, mark out

entries.meaning: (of people) To choose or intend (someone) for a particular end or purpose.
examples: Synonyms: destine, mark out, target

entries.meaning: To be a point in time or space at which something takes place; to accompany or be accompanied by (an event, action, etc.); to coincide with.
examples: The creek marks the boundary between the two farms.
That summer marked the beginning of her obsession with cycling.
Synonyms: represent, see

entries.meaning: To be typical or characteristic of (something).
examples: Synonyms: characterize, typify

entries.meaning: To distinguish (one person or thing from another).
examples: Despite their obvious differences these poets had a common view of life which marks them from their predecessors  […]

entries.meaning: (dated except in the phrase "mark my words") To focus one's attention on (something or someone); to pay attention to, to take note of.
examples: Synonyms: heed, listen to, look at, observe, watch
Mark my words: that boy’s up to no good.

entries.meaning: (dated) To become aware of (something) through the physical senses.
examples: Synonyms: hear, note, notice, observe, perceive, see

entries.meaning: To hold (someone) in one's line of sight.
examples: I marked my man, standing on the catwalk, and waited to throw [my javelin] till he started to climb inboard before they rammed.

entries.meaning: To indicate the correctness of and give a score to (a school assignment, exam answers, etc.).
examples: The teacher had to spend her weekend marking all the tests.
Synonyms: grade, score

entries.meaning: To record that (someone) has a particular status.
examples: to mark a student absent.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To keep account of; to enumerate and register; to keep score.
examples: to mark the points in a game of billiards or a card game

entries.meaning: (sports) To follow a player not in possession of the ball when defending, to prevent them receiving a pass easily.
(Australian rules football) To catch the ball directly from a kick of 15 metres or more without having been touched in transit, resulting in a free kick.
(golf) To put a marker in the place of one's ball.
(singing) To sing softly, sometimes an octave lower than usual, in order to protect one's voice during a rehearsal.

description: From Middle English mark, from Old English marc (“a denomination of weight (usu. half a pound), mark (money of account)”), from Proto-Germanic *marką (“mark, sign”), from Proto-Indo-European *marǵ- (“edge, boundary, border”). As a former German currency, a calque of German Mark. Cognate with Dutch mark (“mark”), Swedish mark (“a stamped coin”), Icelandic mörk (“a weight, usu. a pound, of silver or gold”). Doublet of markka.

entries.meaning: (historical) A half pound, a traditional unit of mass equivalent to 226.8 g.
(historical) Similar half-pound units in other measurement systems, chiefly used for gold and silver.
examples: As a reward for his poetry, Athelstan gave Egil two more gold rings weighing a mark each, along with an expensive cloak that the king himself had worn.

entries.meaning: (historical) A half pound, a former English and Scottish currency equivalent to 13 shillings and fourpence and notionally equivalent to a mark of sterling silver.
examples: George, on receiving it, instantly rose from the side of one of them, and said, in the hearing of them all, ‘I will bet a hundred merks that is Drummond.’

entries.meaning: (historical) A former currency of Germany and West Germany.
(historical) Other similar currencies notionally equal to a mark of silver or gold.

description: An alternate form supposedly easier to pronounce while giving commands.

entries.meaning: (imperative, marching) Alternative form of march.
examples: Mark time, mark!
Forward, mark!
